Article.Abstract: The importance of CD8(+) cytolytic T cells for protection from viral infection and in the generation of immune responses against tumors has been well established. In contrast, the role of CD4(+) T-helper cells in human infection and in cancer immunity has yet to be clearly defined. In this pilot study, we show that immunization of three resected, high-risk metastatic melanoma patients with a T-helper epitope derived from the melanoma differentiation antigen, melanoma antigen recognized by T cells-1, results in CD4(+) T-cell immune responses. Immune reactivity to that epitope was detected by DR4-peptide tetramer staining, and enzyme-linked immunospot assay of fresh and restimulated CD4(+) T cells from patients over the course of the 12-month vaccine regimen. The postvaccine CD4(+) T cells exhibited a mixed T-helper 1/T-helper 2 phenotype, proliferated in response to the antigen and promiscuously recognized the peptide epitope bound to different human leukocyte antigen-DRbeta alleles. For 1 DRbeta1*0401(+) patient, antigen-specific CD4(+) T cells recognized human leukocyte antigen-matched antigen-expressing tumor cells, secreted granzyme B, and also exhibited cytolysis that was MHC class II-restricted. These data establish the immunogenicity of a class II epitope derived from a melanoma-associated antigen and support the inclusion of class II peptides in future melanoma vaccine therapies.
Article.ArticleTitle: Immune responses to a class II helper peptide epitope in patients with stage III/IV resected melanoma.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Medicine, Keck/University of Southern California School of Medicine, Los Angeles, California 90089, USA.

SecondInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Patients were immunized once monthly for the first 6 months, then once every 3 months for the subsequent 6 months, for a total of eight vaccinations over 1 year.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Positive values were shown at 6 months post-vaccine time point, with very low prevaccine background levels.

SecondInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Patients were immunized once monthly for the first 6 months, then once every 3 months for the subsequent 6 months, for a total of eight vaccinations over 1 year.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Subsequent booster immunizations were given at months 9 and 12 of the vaccine regimen and resulted in increased recall responses observed at or after the twelfth month of the trial for each patient.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Positive values were shown at 6 month and 12 month post-vaccine time points, with very low prevaccine background levels.

SecondInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Patients were immunized once monthly for the first 6 months, then once every 3 months for the subsequent 6 months, for a total of eight vaccinations over 1 year.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Data for other two immunized patients not shown. Positive responses were shown for 6 and 12 months post-vaccination. The T2.DR4 (DRB1*0401+) cell line and was used as a target cell.

SecondInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Patients were immunized once monthly for the first 6 months, then once every 3 months for the subsequent 6 months, for a total of eight vaccinations over 1 year.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Four DRB1*0401+/MART-1+ melanoma cell lines were used as target cells, including 624mel, 697mel, 1102mel, and 1359mel. Positive responses were shown at 6 and 12 months post-vaccination. Data for other two immunized patients not shown. IL-5 responses were not detected.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Data for other two immunized patients not shown. Antigen-specific lysis was detected with maximal specific lysis at approximately 30% at effector:target ratios of 60:, which was completely abrogatedby the addition of an anti-MHC class II antibody. The addition of an anti-Fas antibody to the assay did not inhibit cell-mediated lysis The T2.DR4 (DRB1*0401+) cell line was used as a target cell.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Data is presented for one patient, but not for the other two immunized patients. Data analysis was performedthrough sequential gating on CD3+ and CD4+ populations toobtain the percentage of tetramer+ in the total CD4+ T-cellpopulation. The response was shown at post-vaccine time points of 6 and 12 months.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Postvaccine (6 months) samples for all 3 of the patients demonstrated higher proliferation to MART-151–73 than respective prevaccine samples. Assay involved CD8+-depleted PBMCs were stimulated with peptide for 5 days.
